journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part G: Journal of Aerospace Engineering

title-group.article-title: Numerical modelling of a low Reynolds number plunging airfoil flow field characteristics

article-meta.aff: Department of Aerospace Engineering, Ryerson University, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Hekmat Alighanbari, Department of Aerospace Engineering, Ryerson University, 350 Victoria Street, Toronto, Ontario M5B 2K3, Canada. Email: halighan@ryerson.ca

abstract.p: Complex viscous mechanisms such as leading edge vortices play a dominant role in the generation of instantaneous force and moment in low Reynolds number flows. The dependence of the corresponding fluid flow characteristics on the governing flow and system parameters in unsteady motions, e.g. plunging, adds to the inherent complexity of the problem. The respective fluid dynamics of such a flow is investigated here via computational fluid dynamics based on a finite volume method. The governing equations are the unsteady, incompressible two-dimensional Navier–Stokes equations. The flow field and vortical patterns around a thin ellipsoidal plunging airfoil are examined in detail with and without freestream velocity, and the effects of Reynolds and Strouhal numbers on the flow characteristics are explored. It is shown that both Reynolds and Strouhal numbers increase the aerodynamic performance in nonzero freestream velocity simulations. Increasing Reynolds and Strouhal numbers causes the airfoil to generate thrust for some time intervals of the plunging period. This thrust generation is penalized with higher peaks of drag coefficient when Strouhal number increases. However, the same penalty in the Reynolds number effect simulations is negligible compared to that of the Strouhal number effects. Increasing Strouhal number causes the airfoil to experience negative pitching moment with higher peak values for longer time intervals, but Reynolds number does not change the time at which negative pitching moment is exerted on the airfoil, but the peaks of pitching moment depend on the governing Reynolds number. The lift coefficient changes noticeably versus Strouhal number, where there is significant lead/lag at the peak lift coefficient for zero-freestream velocity simulations. Reynolds number effects on the lift coefficients mostly occur around the time at which the peak lift coefficient is obtained for both zero and nonzero freestream velocity cases. All of these effects are caused by the complex vortical patterns around the airfoil, described throughout the present article.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Aerodynamics of oscillating airfoils has been investigated analytically, experimentally and numerically. The existing studies mostly address harmonic pitching, plunging and flapping motions at intermediate and high Reynolds numbers, whereas less attention has been paid to low Reynolds number (LRN) flows. Also, there is a lack of enough research on LRN plunging motions compared to LRN pitching and flapping studies. This unsteady condition is prevalent in a wide range of applications, including micro aerial vehicles (MAVs), fish and marine propulsion and off-shore structures. LRN plunging flows have different aerodynamic characteristics than conventional steady flows. For example, the experimental investigations by Chen and Ho1 showed that LRN plunging airfoils experience a different type of Kutta condition than the one observed in steady flows. These flows also face complex fluid phenomena, which are mainly related to nonlinear vortex shedding such as dynamic stall,2 leading edge vortices (LEVs) and trailing edge vortices (TEVs)3 and wake-capturing mechanism.4,5 In some instances, vortex lock-in phenomenon, which is prevalent in oscillating cylinders, is also observed in transversally oscillating airfoils.6 Governing flow and system parameters such as Strouhal and Reynolds numbers change the characteristics of LRN unsteady flows by affecting the occurring fluid phenomena. Young and Lai7 showed the remarkable influence of reduced frequency and Strouhal number on leading edge flow separation of a plunging airfoil via numerical simulations.

These parameters play a dominant role in the determination of LRN unsteady flow structures and their corresponding nonlinear vortex shedding and response states.8 While this role can be investigated to some extent by classical aerodynamic theories,9,10 these methods result in good accuracy for small deflection assumption.11 Experimental and computational methods are consequently used to obtain the desired higher accuracy. Plunging cylinder visualizations of Lam et al.12 and Techet et al.13 showed the importance of some parameters such as stroke length of oscillations12 and frequency and Reynolds number13 on plunging cylinders wake and vortical patterns. Lua et al.,14 Heathcote and Gursul,15 Freymuth16 and Lai and Platzer17 showed similar dependency of the downstream wakes on the governing parameters by conducting plunging airfoils’ experimental studies, where it also is shown that depending on the governing condition, wakes can be in the form of drag producing, thrust producing or even neutral patterns.16–18

Computational investigations of plunging cylinder wake modes and energy transfer by Leontini et al.19 and Young and Lai7 also revealed the significance of the governing parameters, where the dependence could be different for sinusoidal and nonsinusoidal plunging motions.20 An et al.,21 Chandar and Damodaran22 and Lewin and Haj-Hariri23 simulations also confirmed the significance of the governing parameters to propulsive characteristics and thrust generation,21 force signatures22 and power and thrust coefficients and aerodynamic performance23 of heaving airfoils, where chordwise flexibility could contribute to a more aerodynamically efficient airfoil than a rigid one.24

As mentioned in the preceding paragraphs, the LRN underlying fluid phenomena, e.g. wake-capturing mechanism, and their dependence on the governing parameters are addressed in the literature to some extent; however, the details of the flow structures, effective parameters on the aerodynamics and the significance of each phenomenon under different conditions are not thoroughly understood. The objective of the present study is to improve the existing understanding of LRN plunging airfoil flow characteristics and how it is affected by the governing flow and system parameters. To this end, the flow field of an elliptic airfoil under harmonically heaving motion is simulated using FVM-based CFD and laminar incompressible N-S equations. Two-dimensional (2D) LRN unsteady studies are extremely useful in understanding the flow characteristics and can assist in evaluating the dependence of the aerodynamic performance on different parameters such as the amplitude of oscillation. These investigations also provide a basis for the respective 3D analyses, where the 2D and 3D results are compared, helping in revealing the effectiveness of the 3D aspects, such as tip vortices, spanwise flow, and vortex interactions. In the present 2D study, the effects of Reynolds and Strouhal numbers on the instantaneous lift, drag and moment coefficients at both zero and nonzero freestream velocities are investigated. These parameters have been shown to be of great importance to the fluid dynamics characteristics of pitching,25 plunging,26 and flapping27 airfoils. The pressure fields and vortical structures of the model are also investigated in detail. The computations are carried out in Open FOAM.28

In what follows, solution method, governing equations and computational settings as well as the method for the force and moment signature calculations are presented the solution method section, followed by the spatial and temporal sensitivity analyses along with the validation studies in the investigation of numerical setup section. In the results and discussion section, the effects of Strouhal and Reynolds numbers on the lift, drag and moment coefficients are presented, followed by the main conclusions obtained in this study.

sec.title: Solution method
sec.p: The flow field of a LRN plunging airfoil is governed by the continuity and incompressible N-S equations. The nondimensional forms of these equations are (1)∇·U→=0,St∂U→∂τ+ (U→·∇ )U→=-∇p+1Re∇2U→ where U→ = (u, v), τ = t/T (T is the period of plunging oscillations), St and Re are the nondimensional velocity vector, nondimensional time, Strouhal and Reynolds numbers, respectively. Also, p = pressure/ρUref 2, where Uref is the freestream velocity, and for cases with no freestream Uref is the maximum plunging velocity.

The computational domain is discretized using an O-type mesh. The far-field boundary with symmetry condition is set to 30c from the airfoil surface28 to minimize its undesired effects on the airfoil’s surrounding flow field.21,28 The present simulations are conducted for both zero and nonzero freestream velocities. The inlet and outlet are set to symmetry condition in zero freestream velocity simulations. For nonzero freestream simulations, the inlet is set to a velocity Dirichlet and zero-gradient pressure condition, and the outlet is set to freestream pressure and zero-gradient velocity. The airfoil surface is set to a no-slip boundary condition. The computations utilize 48 × 103 cells and 2000 time steps per period. The grid is composed of 8800 cells within one chord-length of the airfoil such that there are 176 nodes tangentially and 50 nodes radially. Radial spacing is used such that the distance of the first node from the airfoil surface is 0.002c. This choice was made after extensive grid and time step independence analyses, which will presented in the next section. Figure 1 shows the schematic of the airfoil and the computational domain. Figure 1.
Schematic of the airfoil and the computational domain.

Finite volume method (FVM) is used to investigate the aerodynamic characteristics of an ellipse with 2% thickness, as thin airfoils are capable of generating high lift for stable hovering motions. The computations utilize a second order central differencing scheme for the convective and diffusive terms and a second order Euler implicit scheme for temporal discretizations. The resulting linear system of equations is treated with a preconditioned conjugate gradient (PCG) solver with incomplete Cholesky (IC) decomposition, and the semi-implicit method for pressure linked equations (SIMPLE) algorithm is used for the pressure–velocity coupling. The computations are carried out in OpenFOAM,29 and the mesh motion is based on the Laplace smoothing mesh motion algorithm.30 In the Laplace smoothing algorithm, the motion of the computational nodes is obtained via a given diffusivity coefficient. In the present study, the diffusion coefficient30 is inversely proportional to the distance of the nodes from the plunging airfoil. The equation of motion is given by (2)y(t)=Y0cos(2πft) where y(t) is the vertical position vector, Y0 is the amplitude of plunging oscillations, and f is the frequency of oscillations.

In this article, the flow field of an airfoil under heaving oscillations (y(t) = Y0cos(2πft)) is simulated with and without freestream velocity (U0 in Figure 2). The corresponding Reynolds (Re) and Strouhal (St) numbers are defined as the following (3)Re=UrefLrefνSt=frefLrefUref where Uref, Lref, fref and ν are the reference velocity, reference length set to the airfoil chord-length, reference frequency set to the frequency of heaving oscillations and kinematic viscosity, respectively. The reference velocity is either the maximum plunging velocity (Uref = y·max) or the freestream velocity (Uref = U0).31 The nondimensional plunging velocity is given by (4)y·(t)Uref=-2πfY0sin(2πft)Uref = {-2π(St)Y0Csin(2πft)U0≠0-sin(2πf)U0=0 Moreover, based on equations (3), Strouhal number for both zero and nonzero freestream cases can be represented by (5)St=frefLrefUref= {fcU0U0≠0,fc2πfY0=c2πY0U0=0
Figure 2.
Schematic of the plunging airfoil.
Therefore, in the nonzero cases, the nondimensional plunging amplitude (Y0/c) is constant (Y0 = c), and in the zero freestream cases St changes Y0/c.

The unsteady force and moment coefficients also need a reference velocity. The instantaneous lift (Cl), drag (Cd), and moment (Cm) coefficients are obtained using the following equations (6)Cl(t)=Fy(t)0.5ρcU2, Cd(t)=Fx(t)0.5ρcU2 Cm=M(t)0.5ρc2U2 where Fy(t) and Fx(t) are the instantaneous forces in y (lift) and x (drag) directions, respectively, M(t) is the instantaneous pitching moment at the airfoil’s mid-chord, c is the chord-length, and ρ is the density. U is calculated using the following equation (7)U=U0 2+y·max 2

sec.title: Investigation of numerical setup
sec.p: In what follows, several simulations are first performed to investigate the grid and time step resolutions (subsection ‘Mesh and time step sensitivity analyses’). In the succeeding subsection (‘Validation studies’), two case studies (also reported by Williamson32 and Guilmineau and Queutey33) are then carried out to further validate the proposed numerical setup. The main numerical results and discussions are presented in the next section.

sec.title: Mesh and time step sensitivity analyses
sec.p:
In order to obtain grid and time-independent solutions, several cases with different grid size and time step resolutions are examined. The results of these analyses are shown in Figure 3(a) and (b) for the plunging ellipsoidal airfoil at St = 0.16 and Re = 100, when U0 = 0. First, the grid sensitivity is investigated using 24, 48, and 96 (×103) cells and 2000 time steps per plunging cycle. Figure 3(a) shows the obtained Cl versus τ for a half stroke of the airfoil motion; the second half stroke has been omitted because it has the same profile as that of the first half but with the opposite values. As shown, the difference between 48 and 96 (×103) cell cases is negligible; hence 48 × 103 is sufficiently refined to yield grid independent solutions. The time step is also varied for 1000, 2000, and 4000 time steps within a cycle having 48 × 103 cells. The results show that the difference between the lift coefficients of 2000 and 4000 time step cases is negligible (Figure 3(b)). Therefore, the computations are performed using 48 × 103 cells and 2000 time steps. Figure 3.
Cl vs. τ for St = 0.16, Re = 100, and U0 = 0: (a) 2000 time steps per plunging cycle – (−) 24 × 103, (+) 48 × 103, (×) 96×103 cells; (b) 48 × 103 cells – (−) 1000, (+) 2000, (×) 4000 time steps.

Moreover, a sensitivity study about the farfield location is performed by moving the farfield to 40c. The number of cells within one chord-length from the airfoil is fixed to 8800 cells, while the outside region (Figure 1) is extended to 40c with the required increase in the number of cells such that the grid sizes are equivalent to those of the 30c case. Indeed, 48 × 103 is increased to 61.5 × 103 cells, and the Cl versus τ is investigated for St = 0.16, Re = 100 and U0 = 0. Figure 4 shows that there is a very negligible difference between the lift coefficients of 30c and 40c cases, mainly around the peak lift values. Figure 4.
Cl vs. τ for different farfield locations: (*), 30c with 48 × 103cells; (+), 40c with 61.5 × 103 cells.

sec.title: Validation studies
sec.p:
The first validation case, also studied by Williamson,32 is the flow field of a static cylinder at Re = 150. The mean drag coefficient (C¯d) is the benchmark for the comparison. The present simulation gives C¯d = 1.375 which is in very close agreement (3% difference) with C¯d = 1.334, reported by Williamson.32 Figure 5 shows the computed instantaneous Cd versus time (t). The obtained Strouhal number (after a steady vortex shedding is obtained) is 0.183, which matches very well with the ‘universal’ Strouhal–Reynolds number relation given by Williamson,32 St = 0.18. Figure 5.
Cd vs. t for a static cylinder at Re = 150.

The second validation case is a plunging cylinder at Re = 185, reported by Guilmineau and Queutey.33 The motion is governed by the following equation (8)y(t)=-Aesin(2πfet), with Ae = 0.2c (c being the cylinder diameter) and fe = 0.154. The resulting C¯d is 1.25 which is in close agreement (4% difference) with that reported by Guilmineau and Queutey,33 C¯d = 1.2. Figure 6 shows the obtained instantaneous Cd and Cl versus t. Figure 6.
Cl and Cd vs. t of a plunging cylinder at Re = 185.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: In this section, numerical simulations of a thin plunging ellipse (2% thickness) are conducted. The effects of St and Re on the force and moment signatures (Cl, Cd and Cm) and on the vortical patterns surrounding the airfoil, for both zero and nonzero freestream velocities, are investigated. All the presented results show steady solutions after the transient terms fade away

sec.title: Effect of the Strouhal number without freestream flow
sec.p:
In this subsection, the effect of St on the airfoil lift coefficients at Re = 100 is investigated for St = 0.32, 0.16 and 0.11, corresponding to Y0/c = 0.5, 1 and 1.5, respectively. Figure 7 shows Cl versus τ for one plunging cycle. As can be seen, increasing Y0/c (decreasing St) decreases the maximum lift coefficient (Cl,max). That is, Cl,max = 13.2, 8.8 and 6.6, at St = 0.32, 0.16 and 0.11, respectively. This decreasing effect is associated with a lead in the generation of Cl,max. The maximum lift coefficient is obtained at τ = 0.2, 0.12 and 0.1 at St = 0.32, 0.16 and 0.11, respectively. Similarly, the magnitude of the minimum lift coefficient (Cl,min) is decreased, and Cl,min is obtained at τ = 0.7, 0.62, and 0.6 for St = 0.32, 0.16, and 0.11. Figure 7.
Cl vs. τ when Re = 100 and U0 = 0: (−) St = 0.32, (+) St = 0.16, (×) St = 0.11.

Figure 8(a) to (c) show the pressure field around the airfoil when Cl,max is obtained. In these figures, the black color shows low pressure, while the white-coloured areas indicate high pressure. As can be seen, the pressure field at St = 0.32 has two symmetric low-pressure zones at the LE and TE of the airfoil. These regions show LE and TE vortices, which enhance the lift coefficient. The vortices are also stretched and deflected towards the lower surface of the airfoil and surround the high-pressure zone. Decreasing Strouhal number from St = 0.32 to 0.16 generates smaller low-pressure zones with lower strength (brighter color), which results in the decreased Cl,max. The LE and TE vortices are further deflected into the downstream of the airfoil when St is changed from 0.16 to 0.11, which is the reason for the decreased Cl,max. Figure 8.
Pressure contours when Cl,max is achieved at Re = 100 and U0 = 0: (a) St = 0.32, (b) St = 0.16, (c) St = 0.11.

sec.title: Effect of the Strouhal number with freestream flow
sec.p: Here, the effect of St on Cl, Cd and Cm of the plunging airfoil is investigated for St = 0.08, 0.16 and 0.32, where Uref in equations (8) is the freestream velocity. According to the following discussions, it is found that increasing St increases peak lift coefficients significantly. The magnitudes of the peak lift coefficients are almost equal in up- and down-strokes; however, at the highest investigated St, secondary peaks are induced into the instantaneous lift followed by smaller peaks in down-stroke compared to that in the up-stroke. Moreover, increasing St decreases drag coefficients such that at the highest considered St, thrust is generated by the airfoil, penalized by the increased maximum drag coefficients. The peaks of the pitching moment coefficient also strongly depend on the governing St, and the time interval at which the airfoil is subjected to negative or positive moment is changed with respect to St. Moreover, calculation of the aerodynamic performance (C¯l/C¯d) for up- and down-strokes shows that St increases C¯l/C¯d.

Figure 9 shows Cl versus τ. It can be observed that increasing St increases Cl,max in both up- and down-strokes. The instantaneous Cl at St = 0.32 shows that there is a secondary peak Cl at τ ≈ 0.6. Moreover, the close examination of the peaks of Cl at St = 0.32 shows that |Cl,min| is less than |Cl,max|, which is accompanied by the generation of the observed secondary peak. Moreover, the influence of St on Cl,max is more than that on the Cl,min, which could also be related to the generation of the inflection point at τ ≈ 0.6. Figure 9.
Cl vs. τ for Re = 100, Y0 = c and U0 ≠ 0: (−) St = 0.08, (+) St = 0.16, (×) St = 0.32.

Figure 10 shows Cd versus τ. Increasing St from 0.08 to 0.16 is beneficial to Cd as the drag coefficient is reduced. The changes resemble a down-shift of Cd with Cd,max = 0.26 and 0.13 and Cd,min = 0.127 and 0.01 for St = 0.08 and 0.16, respectively. Further increase of St from 0.16 to 0.32 shows an interesting behavior. The drag producing airfoil at St = 0.08 and 0.16 is capable of producing thrust at St = 0.32 between 0.2 < τ < 0.57 and 0.76 < τ < 1. The generated thrust could be of high importance to applications such as forward flight and fish-like locomotion; however, this benefit is gained with the expense of increased Cd around the second Cd,max, between St = 0.16 and 0.32. It should also be mentioned that Cd,max and Cd,min are obtained with negligible lead and lag, respectively, between St = 0.08 and 0.16. However, all the peak drag coefficients (Cd,max and Cd,min) are obtained with significant lag at St = 0.32. The effect of St on Cd,min (drag coefficient at St = 0.08 and 0.16 and thrust coefficient at St = 0.32) is investigated in more details on the airfoil’s vortical patterns in Figure 11(a) to (c). It is seen from these figures that by increasing St, the LEV is strengthened and leans towards the airfoil surface. The TEV is also strengthened, where these changes cause the first Cd,min to decrease versus St and eventually converts into a thrust coefficient (Cd,min < 0) at St = 0.32. Figure 10.
Cd vs. τ for Re = 100, Y0 = c and U0 ≠ 0: (−) St = 0.08, (+) St = 0.16, (×) St = 0.32.
Figure 11.
Vorticity contours around the airfoil when first Cd,min is obtained for Y0 = c, Re = 100 and U0 ≠ 0: (a) St = 0.08; (b) St = 0.16; (c) St = 0.32.

Figure 12 shows Cm versus τ. As it is observed, St has significant effects on both Cm,min and Cm,max, where |Cm,min| is consistently increased, which could be a negative trend from a stability perspective. However, the effect of St on |Cm,max| does not follow a constant trend, meaning that |Cm,max| initially decreases between St = 0.08 and 0.16, and then increases between St = 0.16 and 0.32. Moreover, the time intervals in which the airfoil is subjected to negative and positive pitching moment coefficients, changes with respect to the governing St. The airfoil encounters negative instantaneous Cm between 0 < τ < 0.32, 0 < τ < 0.38 and 0 < τ < 0.54 for St = 0.08, 0.16 and 0.32, respectively, and it undergoes positive Cm for almost the rest of plunging cycle at the three investigated St values, with the exception of a small period of negative Cm at the end of St = 0.32. Hence, by increasing St, the surrounding fluid flow applies nose-down pitching down moment on the airfoil for a longer time interval. Figure 12.
Cm vs. τ for Re = 100 when U0 ≠ 0: (−) St = 0.08, (+) St = 0.16, (×) St = 0.32.

The average lift and drag coefficients (C¯l and C¯d) are studied and listed in Table 1. The mean force coefficients are calculated for the up- and down-strokes separately. As it can be seen, increasing St increases C¯l, but decreases C¯d, resulting in a higher aerodynamic performance (C¯l/C¯d) in each half stroke. Table 1.
C¯l and C¯d for the investigated St where Re = 100, Y0 = c and U0 ≠ 0.
St Up-stroke Down-stroke
0.08 |C¯l| = 0.838 and |C¯d| = 0.197 |C¯l| = 0.838 and |C¯d| = 0.197
0.16 |C¯l| = 1.304 and |C¯d| = 0.065 |C¯l| = 1.304 and |C¯d| = 0.065
0.32 |C¯l| = 1.977 and |C¯d| = 0.032 |C¯l| = 1.447 and |C¯d| = 0.005

sec.title: Effect of the Reynolds number
sec.p:
In what follows, the effect of Reynolds number (Re) on Cl, Cd and Cm of the plunging airfoil is investigated for Re = 100, 200 and 500, with freestream velocity. The Re effect on the Cl for Re = 50 and 100 without freestream velocity is also studied. The vortical patterns around the airfoil are also investigated at the points of interest. It is found, according to the following discussions, that based on the governing Re (U0 ≠ 0), the airfoil could generate drag and thrust during a plunging cycle, and increasing Re can cause the airfoil to produce thrust for a longer period of the oscillations with the expense of a slightly higher peak of the drag coefficient, i.e. lower thrust. Moreover, increasing Re could increase or decrease the pitching moment coefficient, depending on the position of the airfoil during its plunging motion; however, the time interval at which the airfoil is subjected to negative or positive moment is not a function of Re. Although Re effects on the lift coefficient is minimal compared to those on drag and moment coefficients, these effects occur at different time intervals of the plunging motion. The corresponding vortical patterns show very complex LEV and TEV structures and their interactions. Moreover, it is found that increasing Re increases the aerodynamic performance (C¯l/C¯d), where C¯l and C¯d are the average lift and drag coefficients within a plunging cycle and are calculated for the up- and down-strokes separately. In addition, the simulations without freestream velocity also show that Re only affects Cl in the regions around the peak lift coefficient. Figure 13 shows Cl versus τ for Re = 50 and 100, where Re has negligible effects on Cl in most part of the cycle except for a narrow range of Cl near the Cl,max. Figure 13.
Cl vs. τ when St = 0.16 and U0 = 0: (−), Re = 50; (+), Re = 100.

Figure 14 shows Cl versus τ. Increasing Re from 100 to 200 increases the magnitude of peak lift coefficients. For example, Cl,max ≈ 2.4 and 2.7 at Re = 100 and 200, respectively. In addition to the increased Cl,max, the instantaneous Cl is higher at Re = 200 for. However, it is observed that Re does not increase Cl,max from Re = 200 to 500, and the difference between the real time Cl at Re = 200 and 500 mostly occurs when 0 < τ < 0.17 and 0.5 < τ < 0.67. This behavior could be interpreted as if the lowered viscous forces (increased Reynolds number) affect the lift coefficients more in specific intervals of the plunging motion, based on the governing Re. Moreover, comparing the difference between Cl of Re = 200 and 500 at τ = 0.15 and 0.35 shows that although the airfoil is at the same location at these two nondimensional times, the discrepancy is much higher at τ = 0.15. Indeed, increasing Re from 200 to 500 has more effect on Cl when it moves from y = 0 to y = ymax = Y0 in equation (2). Figure 14.
Cl vs. τ for St = 0.16 when U0 ≠ 0: (−) Re = 100, (+) Re = 200, (×) Re = 500.

Figure 15(a) to (c) shows the vortical patterns around the airfoil when Cl.max is obtained for the considered Re, where the black color shows higher vorticity magnitude. It is observed that the LEV at Re = 100 is more deflected towards trailing edge (TE) than that of Re = 200, while TEV is not changed noticeably between Re = 100 and 200. This explains the increase in Cl,max when Re increases from 100 to 200. The LEV at Re = 500 seems to be stronger and more concentrated than that of Re = 200; however, TEV is shown to have a higher strength, explaining the equality of Cl.max between Re = 200 and 500. Figure 15.
Vorticity contours around the airfoil when Cl,max is obtained for St = 0.16 and U0 ≠ 0: (a) Re = 100; (b) Re = 200; (c) Re = 500.

Figure 16 shows the calculated Cd versus τ. The maximum drag coefficient (Cd,max) is 0.132, 0.115 and 0.08, at Re = 100, 200 and 500, respectively, showing that increasing Re decreases Cd,max. This behavior can be investigated in Figure 17(a) to (c), presenting the vortical patterns around the airfoil when Cd,max is obtained (τ ≈ 0.52). Figure 17(a) shows that there is a LEV mostly concentrated around LE, which sweeps on the airfoil’s pressure side by increasing Re, stretches towards TE, but is not separated at any of the considered Re. On the suction side, however, there is a complex vortical pattern; a LEV which is deflected and stays around the TE is strengthened by increasing Re. It seems that there is a secondary circulation region at Re = 100 around LE, attached to the airfoil suction side. Increasing Re from 100 to 200 (Figure 17(b)) causes this secondary vortical pattern to detach from the surface, which is eventually strengthened at Re = 500 (Figure 17(c)). Moreover, a TEV nonexisting at Re = 100, is formed at Re = 200 (Figure 17(b) and (c)). This TEV is also deflected towards LE, although there is freestream velocity. This TEV is strengthened at Re = 500 and is more interacted with the secondary LEV (Figure 17(c)). This complex vortical pattern causes Cd,max to decrease by increasing Re. Figure 16.
Cd vs. τ for St = 0.16 when U0 ≠ 0: (−) Re = 100, (+) Re = 200, (×) Re = 500.
Figure 17.
Vorticity contours around the airfoil when Cd,max at τ = 0.52 is obtained for St = 0.16 and U0 ≠ 0: (a) Re = 100; (b) Re = 200; (c) Re = 500.

Another interesting effect of Re is that increasing Re also causes the airfoil to generate thrust. The plunging airfoil only generates drag at Re = 100 (Figure 16). However, for some intervals of the plunging motion, the airfoil generates thrust at Re = 200. In fact, for Re = 200, thrust is produced within 0.15 < τ < 0.35 and 0.65 < τ < 0.85 intervals. It should also be mentioned that Cd,min = 0.01 at Re = 100, decreases to Cd,min = −0.04 (thrust) at Re = 200. Increasing Re from 200 to 500 decreases the magnitude of Cd,min; however, the airfoil generates thrust for a longer period of time; 0.12 < τ < 0.36 and 0.62 < τ < 0.86. Moreover, the first Cd,min is obtained with lead at τ ≈ 0.28, 0.25 and 0.23, for Re = 100, 200 and 500, respectively, whereas, the calculated Cd,max does not show a significant lead or lag, compared to those observed for Cd,min.

The pitching moment coefficient (Cm) is an important parameter from control and stability perspectives. The effect of Re on Cm versus τ is shown in Figure 18. It is observed that the airfoil faces negative Cm for τ < 0.4 and positive Cm for τ > 0.4. Increasing Re increases |Cm| for τ < 0.4. For example, |Cm,max| increases when Re increases, where the corresponding vortical patterns are shown in Figure 19(a) to (c). It should be mentioned that as Cm,max between 0 < τ < 0.4 is negative, it could be concluded the counter clockwise circulation of the TEV has more influence on the calculated Cm than that of the LEV. Re has an inverses effect on Cm when 0.4 < τ < 1, with the exception of 200 < Re < 500 and 0.66 < τ < 0.8. Figure 18.
Cm vs. τ for St = 0.16 when U0 ≠ 0: (−) Re = 100, (+) Re = 200, (×) Re = 500.
Figure 19.
Vorticity contours around the airfoil when Cm,min at τ = 0.6 is obtained for St = 0.16 and U0 ≠ 0: (a) Re = 100; (b) Re = 200; (c) Re = 500.

The vortical patterns are investigated at τ = 0.6 in Figure 19(a) to (c). Figure 19(a) shows that there is a LEV attached to LE and stretched towards TE. Increasing Re causes this vortex to turn closer to the airfoil surface and to rotate around the TE at Re = 200. Increasing Re further to 500 causes this vortex to be closer to the surface with a higher strength. Moreover, increasing Re strengthens the TEV. In addition, the flow on the suction side of the airfoil at Re = 100 starts to separate at Re = 200, which eventually forms a secondary vortical pattern at Re = 500. Therefore, the decreasing effect of Re on Cm is accompanied with the very complex vortical behavior, as shown in Figure 19(a) to (c).

Finally, the changes in the average C¯l and C¯d are studied and listed in Table 2. As it can be seen, the magnitude of |C¯l| does not change significantly, but |C¯d| decreases noticeably, resulting in increased |C¯l/C¯d|. Table 2.
C¯l and C¯d for the investigated Re where U0 ≠ 0.
Re Up-stroke Down-stroke
100 |C¯l| = 1.304 and |C¯d| = 0.065 |C¯l| = 1.304 and |C¯d| = 0.065
200 |C¯l| = 1.439 and |C¯d| = 0.028 |C¯l| = 1.439 and |C¯d| = 0.028
500 |C¯l| = 1.411 and |C¯d| = 0.013 |C¯l| = 1.411 and |C¯d| = 0.013

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: Simulations of a two-dimensional plunging airfoil in low Reynolds number flow regime are carried out based on a finite volume method and Navier–Stokes equations. The computations are conducted for both zero and nonzero freestream velocities. The effects of Reynolds number and Strouhal number on the lift, drag, and moment coefficients are investigated and the details of flow patterns and vortical structures are examined. In the simulations of the effects of Strouhal number without freestream velocity, it is found that higher Strouhal number increases the magnitude of the lift coefficients with significant lead/lag, induced into the instantaneous lift coefficients. The lead and lag in the location of the peak lift coefficients are found to be negligible in the simulations of Strouhal number effect with freestream velocity compared to those without freestream. Moreover, including the freestream in the simulation, a secondary peak of lift coefficient is observed at the highest Strouhal number followed by the lower minimum peak lift coefficient than the maximum lift coefficient, where maximum and minimum lift coefficients are almost equal for other Strouhal numbers for both zero and nonzero freestream velocity simulations. Moreover, the nonzero freestream velocity simulations show that drag coefficient decreases with increasing Strouhal number where eventually the airfoil generates thrust at some time intervals during its plunging motion with the expense of a higher maximum drag coefficient. In addition, the airfoil encounters a negative pitching moment for a longer time interval when St increases in nonzero oncoming flow cases. The aerodynamic performance also increases with increasing Strouhal number

Reynolds number affects the lift coefficient mostly around its peak values, an increasing effect. However, the nonzero oncoming flow simulations show that Reynolds number does not change the peak lift coefficients significantly for the range of Reynolds number considered in this study. The drag coefficients is found to decrease when Reynolds number increases, and the initially drag producing airfoil, generates thrust for some time intervals during the motion. Further increase of Reynolds number causes the airfoil to generate thrust for a longer period, penalized by a slightly higher drag coefficient (lower thrust coefficient). Unlike the effects of St on the pitching moment, Reynolds number does not change the time interval for which negative or positive pitching moment is exerted on the airfoil, but Reynolds number changes the peaks of the pitching moment coefficient. Moreover, Reynolds number increases the aerodynamic performance in the nonzero oncoming velocity computations.

The conclusions drawn from this work show that all the mentioned effects of Strouhal number and Reynolds numbers are the direct results of leading/trailing edge vortex patterns, their interactions and secondary vortical patterns generated during the plunging motion, well explaining the need for more studies on the aerodynamics of oscillating airfoil/wings in low Reynolds number flow regime.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received financial support by the Ryerson University and the Natural Sciences and Engineering Council of Canada (NSERC).
